author: Jimmy Nsubuga
title: Pret a Manger backtracks on unpaid internships after backlash
text:
Pret a Manger will pay interns with real money (Picture: Getty Images) Pret a Manger have told Metro.co.uk they plan to pay teenage interns with actual money after initially offering them sandwiches instead.
The clocks go forward tomorrow - don't get caught out The decision came after the food outlet faced backlash for offering unpaid summer internships to 16- to 18-year-olds.
Angry social media users said they were planning to boycott Pret as a result of the unpaid placements.
Here’s how Twitter reacted: I will never eat in Pret a Manger @Pret ever again. #BOYCOTT pic.twitter.com/2P5YGOhm14 
— TapWin™ (@tapwin) March 25, 2017 
He also wasn’t happy Dear Pret a Manger . If you expect me to pay for the food & drinks in your outlets, I expect you to pay the staff who make & serve it.
— Kenny // K404 (@K404ExtremeOC) March 25, 2017 
She compared it to national service Imagine: the government brings back national service, but instead of serving in the army you have to work in Pret a Manger
— Laura (@LizzleAlstizzle) March 25, 2017 

But Pret a Manger has now backtracked, with its CEO Clive Schlee promising to pay the 500 interns.
‘Pret’s Work Experience Week is not about making sandwiches for free,’ he told Metro.co.uk.
‘We set it up so that 16-18 year olds can shadow our teams and get a flavour for what working at Pret is like.
‘We’ve seen how passionately people feel about the initiative, and in response I would like to confirm that we will pay all participants Pret’s starting hourly rate and of course provide free food as well.’
MORE: Fears London attacker was radicalised inside UK prison 
Interns were going to get sandwiches instead (Picture: Getty Images) The company is reportedly in danger of not having enough staff due to Brexit as only one in 50 applicants are British.
It is worried leaving the European Union will mean it has less access to foreign workers so bosses have launched a summer intern programme for young British people.
Pret a Manger said the youngsters would ‘get exposure to aspects of our business including food production, customer service, social responsibility (care for the homeless) and financial control’.
